div1.head: Jim to Mon. Paul A. Rockwell July 1st 1915
div1.p: Thanks for your newsy letter the 29th.

I was greatly surprised at the developments re our boy Hall. That lemon Winslow has been pulling the same sort of line to Sayles. Are you sure its not Winslow? He’s gone back to Paris and is beefing about being called home for the movilization. Norman predicted that Hall woule follow in the foot steps of Cowden and take the “cure” but its hard to say. As we all know he’s an awful lier [sic] and hot air artist, and every time he sees a fire on the ground he comes rushing back and reports bringing down a Boche but I believe he has the where with all in a pinch. We’ll have a long talk all around when you come out and be damned sure to come.

The Capt. is off on permission. Lieut is running us. He’s a wild one and needs a few bullets near him to tame him down. This morning he led us 20 kilometers inside the lines and we kept diving on Boches there that were in far greater numbers. Also thru [sic] new avatiks that went so fast we looked as if tied. Couple of Fokkers in the mix up but there
was no battle. The Lieut got into a vrille and spun down from 3,000 meters to 500 feet. We thought it was all off. He’ll keep this “Nach Berlin” stuff up once too many times and about a half of us will stay over there. Its fool work and does no good. Kiffin’s sore on him for being so wild. The outfit seems to have tamed down, anyway, having learnt that there are certain precautions to follow. When we first got here no one knew anything about this aerial warfare as conducted at present and it took some while to learn.
Peculiar Skipper hasn’t shown up yet. He’s been asked for a long time back.
Don’t know how Grundy’s pay is yet. Hope for first square up at the beginning of this month.
I can’t get over old Victor. I run across things all the time reminding me of him and I realize what a fine character has been lost to the world.
Hurry up and come out. My love to Mrs. Weeks.
